title: 110_hr5749
content: The "Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2008" includes provisions for Federal-State agreements, an emergency unemployment compensation account, payments to States, financing provisions, fraud and overpayments regulations, definitions, and applicability. The "Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2008" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all regular benefits and are not receiving compensation from other sources. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2008 allows states to provide emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. This includes situations where no more regular compensation is available or when rights to compensation have expired. The amount of emergency unemployment compensation is based on the regular compensation payable under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2008 allows states to provide emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. State laws regarding regular compensation apply to emergency compensation, with a maximum amount set for each individual. Governors in extended benefit periods can choose to pay emergency compensation before extended benefits. Unauthorized aliens are ineligible for this assistance. Unauthorized aliens are ineligible for emergency unemployment compensation under the Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2008. Eligibility requires legal authorization to work in the United States, following procedures outlined in the Social Security Act. SEC. 3. EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The Emergency Unemployment Compensation Account established by the Act provides eligible individuals with an account based on their benefit year. The amount in the account is determined by a percentage of total regular compensation or 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. The Emergency Unemployment Compensation Account provides individuals with an account based on their benefit year, determined by a percentage of total regular compensation or 13 times the average weekly benefit amount. If an individual's account is exhausted during an extended benefit period in their State, the account will be augmented by the original amount established. The Emergency Unemployment Compensation Account provides individuals with an account based on their benefit year. If an individual's account is exhausted during an extended benefit period in their State, the account will be augmented by the original amount established. Additionally, a period would be in effect for a State under certain conditions specified in the Act. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments to states with agreements for emergency unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals under the agreement. States will not receive payment for compensation already reimbursed under other federal laws. The amount payable to each state will be determined by the Secretary in advance or as reimbursement based on estimated entitlement under this Act. The Secretary may adjust payments to states based on prior estimates, using agreed-upon methods. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds from the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund are used to make payments to States with agreements under this Act. The Secretary certifies payments to States, and the Treasury makes payments to States accordingly. Funds are appropriated to assist States from the employment security administration account of the Unemployment Trust Fund. The Secretary estimates necessary appropriations for payments under the Act, including compensation under title 5 of the United States Code and services under the Internal Revenue Code. Appropriated funds do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. If an individual knowingly makes a false statement or fails to disclose a material fact to receive emergency unemployment compensation they are not entitled to, they will be ineligible for further compensation and may face prosecution. They must repay any wrongly received compensation unless the State agency waives the repayment. State agency may waive repayment if individual not at fault and repayment is against equity. State agency can recover overpayment by deducting from future unemployment compensation, not exceeding 50%. The State agency can recover overpayments by deducting from future unemployment compensation, not exceeding 50% of the weekly benefit amount. Repayment and deductions require a fair hearing and final determination. Any State agency determination can be reviewed similar to determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as compensation, benefit year, State, and week according to the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. Emergency unemployment compensation under this Act applies to weeks of unemployment starting after the agreement is entered into and ending on or before March 31, 2009. For individuals with remaining amounts in their account by the last day of the last week before March 31, 2009, compensation will continue to be payable from those amounts if eligibility requirements are met. If the account is exhausted after that last week, it will not be augmented. No compensation shall be payable after June 30, 2009, regardless of the individual's State's extended benefit period. The House of Representatives passed the document on June 12, 2008, with Lorraine C. Miller as Clerk and Robert F. Reeves as Deputy Clerk.
